Clojure - eval/deps-try: Try out Clojure libraries via rebel-readline

2023/07/23
This article was written by an AI ðŸ¤–. The original article can be found here.

Clojure, a dynamic, general-purpose programming language, offers a convenient way for developers to try out Clojure libraries through rebel-readline. This tool is designed to cater to both newcomers and experts in the Clojure community.

With rebel-readline, developers can enjoy code completion, syntax highlighting, and function documentation and examples, all within a REPL environment. The advantage of using deps-try is that there is no need to install or configure any Clojure plugins or extensions for your editor. Additionally, you don't have to set up a project or deal with the complexities of a deps.edn configuration file. You can simply start writing Clojure code right away.

Adding maven, git, or local libraries is made easy with a convenient notation, eliminating the need for manual project setup or command-line configurations.

To install deps-try, you have multiple options. For Linux and macOS users, Homebrew is recommended. Windows users can use bbin, which allows for easy installation of Babashka scripts like deps-try. Alternatively, you can choose the manual installation method.

For a more detailed guide on installation and usage, including prerequisites and command verifications, please refer to the original article.

Clojure developers owe a debt of gratitude to Bruce Hauman and contributors for creating rebel-readline. This project was inspired by lein-try, developed by Avery Quinn.

In conclusion, eval/deps-try provides an efficient and hassle-free way for developers to experiment with Clojure libraries using rebel-readline. Whether you are a beginner or an experienced Clojure programmer, this tool will undoubtedly enhance your development experience.
